Maintains specific tension and length of: structure containing a number of nerve cell bodies, physical expansion of spinal chord, connects processes out to muscles.
contains the cell bodies of sensory neurons that bring information from the periphery to the spinal cord. Used in stretch reflex
A collection of nerve cell bodies
(neurite) extends from ganglion to muscle (term used instead of axon/dendrite)
Detects signals from environment, sends a process to the CNS into the inner gray matter
Sensory neuron endings, releases neurotransmitters
Motor neuron, receives neurotransmitters
exists in gray matter of spinal chord, sends signals to muscle via process from CNS
gap, interacts with receptors on post-synaptic cell
Collection of processes, bundle of sensory and motor fibers
incoming signal to CNS - *dorsal root*
outgoing signal from CNS - *ventral root*
synapses with motor neuron are on the motor neuron's *dendrites*
extends an *axon* out to the muscle
reflect who they're connected to (long processes for motor neurons can be 3ft long), where they receive inputs and where they send them
Difficult to distinguish between inputs and outputs, no obvious axon
(unipolar) only one process extends from body
Branch goes up one way and down another
classic neuron, cell body with dendrites on body and single axon
process signals between sensory and motor neurons
2-3 times as many than neurons. 5 kinds
look like stars, common. Provide physical support and nutrients for neurons. Regulate k+ conc outside nervous system. Remove excess neurotransmitters from extracellular space.
Around throughout life of org, important in development. Provide scaffold for migration of neurons.

immune response. made in bone marrow, highly mobile. clean up cellular debris, see a lot near infections or neurodegenerative diseases (Parkison's, Huntington's, Alzheimer's). Excessive activity during development may remove too many synapses leading to issues like possibly autism??

found in CNS (brain, spinal cord) only, generate _myelin_ (flattened cell membrane w/o plasma) from glial cell. Electrical insulator, allows action potentials to move quicker and more reliably. Each _oligodentrocyte_ myelinates several axons.
nodes where AP are generated, gaps in myelin.
glial cells outside the CNS, in the PNS. Provide myelin. Myelantes only _one_ axon. Takes own cell body and wraps around, squeezing out most cytoplasm.
Networks of interconnected neurons, can have activity that spreads throughout the net. Found in Hydras.
network of neurons and ganglia on the gut
